sub_topic: Calculation of magnetic field due to a current-carrying sheet
message_1: A current-carrying sheet has a width of 5 cm, a length of 10 cm, and carries a current of 2 amps. Determine the magnetic field at a point located parallel to the center of the sheet, 3 cm away from its surface.
message_2:
To determine the magnetic field at a point located parallel to the center of the sheet and 3 cm away from its surface, we can use the formula for the magnetic field due to an infinite current-carrying sheet:

B = (μ₀ * I) / (2 * π * d)

where B is the magnetic field, μ₀ is the permeability of free space (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A), I is the current, and d is the distance from the sheet.

In this case, the current I is 2 A, and the distance d is 3 cm (0.03 m). Plugging these values into the formula, we get:

B = (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A * 2 A) / (2 * π * 0.03 m)

B = (8π × 10^(-7) Tm) / (0.06 m)

B ≈ 4.19 × 10^(-5) T

So, the magnetic field at the point parallel to the center of the sheet and 3 cm away from its surface is approximately 4.19 × 10^(-5) Tesla.
